    Chapter 11, Vignette 3: RJafroc functions for ROC sample size estimation using DBMH method

    Dev P. Chakraborty

    2018-11-29

    Ch11V3SampleSize.Rmd

    Introduction

    This illustrates the RJafroc implementation of sample-size estimation. Default \(\alpha\) is 0.05 and default power 1-\(\beta\) is 0.8. Three functions are provided. Each of these functions can be used with method "DBMH" (illustrated here, the default) or method = "ORH" (next vignette) significance testing. Illustrated below are random-reader random-case (RRRC) options only, option = "RRRC". The user should experiment with fixed-reader random-case (FRRC) and random-reader fixed-case (RRFC) options.

    • SsPowerGivenJK() Statistical power for specified numbers of readers and cases in an ROC study.
    • SsPowerTable() Generate a power table, i.e., combinations of numbers of readers and cases yielding the desired power.
    • SsSampleSizeKGivenJ Number of cases, for specified number of readers, to achieve desired power.

    Illustration of SsPowerGivenJK() using method = "DBMH"

    The selected dataset corresponds to the Van Dyke data.

    power <- SsPowerGivenJK(dataset02, J = 6, K = 112)

    The returned value is a list containing the expected power power, the non-centrality parameter ncp, the denominator degrees of freedom ddf and the F-statistic f. The numerator degrees of freedom ndf is always I - 1, i.e., unity for this dataset.

    str(power)
#> List of 12
#>  $ powerRRRC: num 0.556
#>  $ ncpRRRC  : num 4.8
#>  $ ddfHRRRC : num 23.1
#>  $ fRRRC    : num 4.28
#>  $ powerFRRC: num 0.663
#>  $ ncpFRRC  : num 5.76
#>  $ ddfHFRRC : num 111
#>  $ fFRRC    : num 3.93
#>  $ powerRRFC: num 0.729
#>  $ ncpRRFC  : num 10.3
#>  $ ddfHRRFC : num 5
#>  $ fRRFC    : num 6.61

    Expected power is 0.5555789.

    Illustration of SsPowerTable() using method = "DBMH" 

    powTab <- SsPowerTable(dataset02, method = "DBMH")

    Now show the power table powTab.

    Illustration of SsSampleSizeKGivenJ() using method = "DBMH"

    This function ilustrates how the number of cases for 10 readers, used in Vignette 2, were chosen. In each example, the default value of the desiredPower argument is used, namely 0.8 (if the argument is absent, its default value is used).

    RRRC

    ncases <- SsSampleSizeKGivenJ(dataset02, J = 10, method = "DBMH", option = "RRRC")
str(ncases)
#> List of 2
#>  $ KRRRC    : num 163
#>  $ powerRRRC: num 0.802

    ncases is a list containing the number of cases ncases$K and expected power ncases$power.

    Non default value of desiredPower

    This is illustrated below for 90% desired power.

    ncases <- SsSampleSizeKGivenJ(dataset02, J = 10, method = "DBMH", option = "RRRC", desiredPower = 0.9)
str(ncases)
#> List of 2
#>  $ KRRRC    : num 236
#>  $ powerRRRC: num 0.9

    The required number of cases is 236 and expected power is 0.9003501.

    FRRC

    ncases <- SsSampleSizeKGivenJ(dataset02, J = 10, method = "DBMH", option = "FRRC")
str(ncases)
#> List of 2
#>  $ KFRRC    : num 133
#>  $ powerFRRC: num 0.801

    The required number of cases is 133 and expected power is 0.8011167.

    RRFC

    ncases <- SsSampleSizeKGivenJ(dataset02, J = 10, method = "DBMH", option = "RRFC")
str(ncases)
#> List of 2
#>  $ KRRFC    : num 53
#>  $ powerRRFC: num 0.805

    The required number of cases is 53 and expected power is 0.8049666.
